message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Standard translations all use "virtue" for 德 — reconsider?">
New data for the 德 discussion. The passage 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼 (Dao De Jing Ch. 38) has well-established standard English translations:

**D.C. Lau**: "When the way was lost there was virtue; when virtue was lost there was benevolence; when benevolence was lost there was rectitude; when rectitude was lost there were the rites."

**Wing-tsit Chan**: "When the Way is lost, only then do we have virtue; when virtue is lost, only then do we have humanity; when humanity is lost, only then do we have righteousness; when righteousness is lost, only then do we have propriety."

**James Legge**: "When the Tao was lost, its attributes appeared; when its attributes were lost, benevolence appeared; when benevolence was lost, righteousness appeared; when righteousness was lost, the proprieties appeared."

Every major translator uses "virtue" for 德 in this passage. Our decision was "(constitutive) character" instead.

Given this data — does this change your view? Should we:
A) Keep "(constitutive) character" — our reasoned departure from tradition, acknowledged in TN
B) Use the standard "virtue" for the Laozi block quote specifically (since it IS a quotation of a classical text), then switch to "(constitutive) character" when the author begins their own analysis
C) Something else?

Brief response with your recommendation.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**B. Use "virtue" in the Laozi block quote, then switch to "(constitutive) character" when the author begins their analysis.**

This is the right solution because the passage itself enacts a transition from classical text to the author's reinterpretation -- and the translation should make that transition visible.

The Laozi line is a *quotation*. It belongs to Laozi, not to the author. Translating it with standard renderings ("virtue," "benevolence," "righteousness," "propriety") respects the source and gives the English reader the same recognition a Chinese reader has: "ah, this is the famous passage from Chapter 38." If we render it as "(constitutive) character" from the start, we erase the reader's ability to recognize the quotation and compare it with translations they may already know.

Then when the author begins their analysis -- introducing 现象礼, 现象仁, 现象义, and redefining 德 as "that which makes a thing what it is" -- the shift from "virtue" to "character" *performs* the author's philosophical move. The reader sees the standard term replaced by a new one and understands: the author is not using 德 the way Laozi meant it. The terminological shift enacts the conceptual shift.

The TN at the transition point writes itself: "The author now departs from the standard reading of 德 as 'virtue.' In the analysis that follows, 德 is understood as (constitutive) character: the defining characteristics that make a thing what it is, assembled bottom-up from phenomena. See Glossary."

This also dissolves the entire debate we have been having. "Virtue" was never wrong for the Laozi quotation -- it was wrong for the *author's usage*. Option B lets each term serve the context it belongs to.
input.summary: B — "virtue" in Laozi quote, then switch to "character" for author's analysis
